passages.text: August 29, 2025 12:10 PM GMT
Our monthly report summarizes kendata/charts from China to give investors quick insights into China's macro environment and its demand for mineral resources.

China view - deflation fights back: Our economics team for China notes that July activity growth recorded a big miss, echoing their view that real GDP growth could slow to \(4.5\% Y\) in 3Q (vs. \(5.2\% Y\) in 2Q), with payback of export and fiscal frontloading. The slowdown was led by infrastructure capex and durable goods sales, partly owing to stronger- than- seasonal weather disruptions to construction and a short pause in consumption trade- in subsidies. They also expect a Rmb0.5- 1trn supplementary budget and potential front- loading of next year's Rmb2trn local debt swap quota this fall, to mitigate growth slowdown (see report).

Macro - declining production across the board: China's IP was \(+5.7\%\) YoY in July (June \(+6.8\%\) ), with July PMI at 49.3 (June 49.7). July CPI was \(0.0\%\) YoY (June 0.1%). New property starts were \(- 15.2\%\) YoY in July (June \(- 9.5\%\) YoY) and GFA sold fell \(8.4\%\) YoY in July (June \(- 6.6\%\) YoY). Thus, our property team thinks the July Politburo meeting results mesh with their view that housing policy response may be muted until housing prices soften notably consecutively. FAI was \(- 5.3\%\) YoY in July (June - \(0.1\%\) YoY). July aluminum production rose \(0.6\%\) YoY. to \(3.8\mathrm{mmt}\) ; the slight MoM trim in production was probably due to capacity relocation from Shandong to Yunnan.

Commodities data - steel exports remain strong: Steel exports in July grew \(2\%\) MoM and \(26\%\) YoY. to 9.8 Mt, although crude steel output was down \(4.2\%\) YoY in July and domestic steel apparent consumption fell \(6.5\%\) YoY. China's iron ore imports were down \(1\%\) MoM, but up \(2\%\) YoY in July, to 105mnt, while YTD imports were still \(2\%\) lower vs. last year. Despite slowdown of CISA steel output, port inventories have been drawing modestly and iron ore availability has been rising seasonally with improved shipments from Australia and Brazil.

How are we positioned: For met coal exposure, we continue to like WHC.AX (OW) at current levels, generating FY26e FCF yields of \(- 7.6\%\) and \(10.1\%\) on base and spot coal prices, respectively. Earlier in the year, we saw potential for an ASX200 rotation into Resources from a combination of stretched Banks valuations and any further Chinstimulus, with large diversified miners benefiting the most (more here). We continue to prefer BHP (OW) over RIO.AX (EW).
For iron ore our order of preference is MIN.AX (OW), BHP.AX (OW), FMG.AX (OW), RIO.AX (EW), and DRR.AX (EW).
We remain OW S32.AX for base metals exposure, which usually benefits from higher growth.
For lithium, we are OW MIN.AX, OW PLS.AX. and Uw IGO.AX with the market showing some signs of supply discipline coupled with continued strong demand from EV sales (here).
MORGAN STANLEY AUSTRALIA LIMITED+
Rahul Anand, CFA Equity Analyst
Asia Pacific Industry View
Boss Energy Ltd: Messy financials driven by inventories and ramp- up. However, underlying operating headwinds remain. UW. (28 Aug 2025)
Lynas Rare Earths: Raising for growth (28 Aug 2025)
Mineral Resources Limited: Strong FY25, Onslow at nameplate in August, Pilbara IO
Reserves 2x MSe. FY26 guidance slightly lower. Stay OW. (27 Aug 2025)
IGO Ltd: Forrestania C&M leads to miss in EBITDA, Nova C&M remains a key question. Stay
Rio Tinto Plc: Portfolio Simplification - The First Steps (27 Aug 2025)
Rio Tinto Limited: Fatality at Simandou (25 Aug 2025)

New starts were down \(15.2\%\) YoY in July and GFA sold fell \(8.4\%\) YoY, while property completions declined \(29.5\%\) YoY. Our property team thinks the July Politburo meeting results are consistent with their view that housing policy response may be muted until housing prices soften notably consecutively.

Domestic steel apparent consumption decreased \(6.5\%\) YoY in July, amid still high net exports \((+28\%)\) YoY) and some inventory digestion, while key steel mills production declined \(4.0\%\) YoY during the period.
July aluminum production was up \(0.6\%\) YoY, to 3.8mnt. The slight MoM trim in production in July was probably due to minor volume loss due to capacity relocation from Shandong to Yunnan.
July coal production fell \(3.8\%\) YoY and \(9.5\%\) MoM to 381mnt, affected by multiple factors including, overproduction check by NEA and heavy rains in Northwest China.
China's net steel exports were up \(11.4\%\) YoY in July.

Iron ore imports were up \(2\%\) YoY but down \(1\%\) MoM in the month to 105mnt. YTD imports are still \(2\%\) lower vs. last year with CISA steel output, port inventories have been drawing modestly.

Coal imports declined \(23\%\) YoY but grew \(8\%\) MoM in July to 36mnt, with the YTD import decline widening further to \(- 13\%\) (vs. \(- 11\%\) in 6M25). The MoM increase in coal imports is within expectations as the price increase in domestic market has opened the arbitrage window between domestic and Indonesian coal, leading to higher imports.
The following material was published in a report titled: China Materials: July IP Data: Production Declines Across the Board (15 Aug 2025)

Property - new starts - \(15.2\%\) YoY in July (vs. - \(9.5\%\) YoY in June), GFA sold fell \(8.4\%\) YoY (vs. - \(6.6\%\) YoY in June) and property completions - \(29.5\%\) YoY (vs. \(2.2\%\) YoY in June), all based on restated data for 2024. Our property team thinks the July Politburo meeting results are consistent with their view that housing policy response may be muted until housing prices soften notably consecutively.
FAI - \(5.3\%\) YoY in July (- \(0.1\%\) YoY in June). Highway investment (FAI) was - \(16.6\%\) YoY in July, while railways was \(+12.4\%\) YoY.

Crude steel output continued to decline. - \(4.2\%\) MoM/- \(4.0\%\) YoY in July (vs. - \(9.2\%\) YoY in June), consistent with key steel mills' production decline of \(4.0\%\) YoY (rebased) during the period, according to CISA. We estimate domestic steel apparent consumption decreased \(6.5\%\) YoY in July, amid still high net exports (+ \(28\%\) YoY) and some inventory digestion.

**July aluminum production up 0.6% YoY but down 0.8% MoM to 3.8mnt.** The slight MoM trim in production in July was probably due to minor volume loss due to capacity re-election from Shanghai doing to Yunnan. Total aluminum production in 7M25 still saw a 3% YoY increase to 26mnt. As the industry's operating capacity reaches the upper limit with a utilization rate of 96%, we expect the overall aluminum production to remain elevated at current levels heading into year-end.

**Coal monthly production down 3.8% YoY and 9.5% MoM to 381mnt in July,** affected by multiple factors including: 1) overproduction check by NEA in major producing provinces,which resulted in the temporary suspension of few mines; and 2) heavy rains in Northwest China, hampering mine production in Shanxi and Shaanxi. As the weather impact gradually phases out, and if there's no further action from NEA on overproduction inspection, we expect the monthly coal production to recover MoM in August.
Exhibit 1: July industrial production data
Source: National Bureau of Statistics, Morgan Stanley Research. *Note: Railway and highway FAI growth is rebased.
The following material was published in our recent report: China Materials: July Trade Data: Steel exports remain strong (7 Aug 2025)

**Steel exports in July grew 2% MoM and 26% YoY, to 9.8 Mt. 7M25 exports growth** remained high at +11.4% YoY/+6.8 Mt YoY, while the high base in 2H24 should lead to gradual YoY declines. Daily production of CISA member mills decreased 4% YoY in July (vs. -2.5% in June), rebased. Assuming similar YoY growth for nationwide total crude steel production, we estimate apparent steel consumption in July decreased 6.5% YoY and 4.7% MoM.

**China's imports of copper and copper products (refined + alloys) were 480 kt in July, up 3% MoM and 10% YoY to the highest level since March.** The Yangshan premium rebounded slightly compared to the level in June, affected by the 232 tariff on copper. The higher MoM refined copper imports may be due to higher volumes from Russia. Copper ore and concentrate imports rose 9% MoM or 18% YoY to 2.56 mn tonnes, reflecting the higher volume from Grasberg Indonesia as Indonesia's copper import exports permit its expire in September.

**Aluminium and product exports were 542 kt in July, up 11% MoM but down -8% YoY.** The aluminum products producers still have reasonable profits with foil and plate export profits realized at an average of ~250/t and Rmb310/t, respectively, spurred by higher exports in July.

**China's iron ore imports totaled 105 Mt in July, down 1% MoM but up 2% YoY. YTD** **imports are still 2% lower versus last year.** Despite slowdown of CISA steel output, port inventories have been drawing modestly and iron ore availability has been rising seasonally with improved shipments from Australia and Brazil.

**Coal imports declined 23% YoY but grew 8% MoM in July to 36 Mt,** with the YTD import decline widening further to -13% (vs. -11% in 6M25). The MoM increase in coal imports is within expectations as the price increase in domestic market has opened the arbitrage window between domestic and Indonesian coal, leading to higher imports. As coal supply in domestic market remains sufficient, coal import volume should stay on YoY declining trend in the remaining months of the year.
Exhibit 2: China: July trade data
Source: General Administration of Customs, Morgan Stanley Research.

- July PMI +49.3 (June +49.7). July Industrial production was +5.7% YoY (June +6.8%).- July CPI rises 0.0% YoY (0.1% June), while PPI fell -3.6% YoY (-3.6% June).- Power generation rises 3.1% YoY in July vs. a rise of 1.7% YoY in June.- New loans in July were up 8.8% YoY to Rmb-50.0bn (June Rmb2240bn, +8.3% YoY).

Property sales dropped at a faster pace vs. June, with falling prices in July amid higher inventory. Weakened resident sentiment and a reactive policy may put extra pressure on home prices in coming months. Our China Property team suggests sticking with quality SOEs with high visibility for alpha; CR Land is their Top Pick. See: China Property: Monthly Tracker: July Data Worsened on All Fronts; We Expect the Weak Trend to Continue (18 Aug 2025)
The following was published in the report: Greater China Materials: Weekly Monitor: Steel Mills Curb Production Ahead of Sept 3 Parade (22 Aug 2025)

China's July net steel exports rose \(+2\%\) MoM, annualising at \(\sim 113\) mtpa, but remain elevated in the context of the total seaborne market. Our China materials team sees prospects of a gradual decline into year- end as talks about capacity curbs continue.
See: China Steel Exports: July - no signs of retrenchment yet (7 Aug 2025)

Coking coal price rally encountered slight pullback while QHD inventory continued to pile up for the third week in a row. The output of thermal coal remains at a low level due to heavy rain in the Northwest regions including Shanxi, Shaanxi, and Inner Mongolia, which has affected the production of some open- pit coal mines. However, as the weather effects fade, production should gradually recover, combined with the decreasing daily consumption of power plants, the overall pressure on thermal coal prices still persists.
See: China Coal: Weekly Coal Update: Weak Thermal Coal Production (25 Aug 2025)
The following material was published in the report titled: China Coal: Weekly Coal Update: Weak Thermal Coal Production (25 Aug 2025)

Base metals have been range- bound in recent months as macro and supply- demand indicators give little clear direction. Our commodities team analyses key drivers of copper, aluminium and zinc, and how these have evolved since their recent price deck.
For further details, see metal&ROCK: Base Metals Round Up (22 Aug 2025)

Diverging market forces leave base metals rangebound: Metals markets have struggled to find direction in recent months. China is taking small policy steps in the right direction, with recent social welfare measures and some infrastructure investment, and US tariff rates are currently lower than anticipated. On top, our FX strategists' view of a weakening USD ahead should be supportive for commodities more broadly. However, economic growth concerns remain, as the effects of tariffs are felt over time, while some of the metals demand indicators in China are showing signs of slowing sequentially.

Modest downside for LME copper: The support for LME copper prices that came from US front- loading demand ahead of expected copper import tariffs is likely to fade after the decision to exclude refined copper. We estimate front loading YTD added around \(2\%\) to annual copper demand, drawing down ex- US inventories and supporting prices, but now leaves the US very well stocked. China demand indicators are also softening, bringing a cautious outlook to LME copper. However, recent supply challenges, an open China import arb and a weakening USD are likely to limit downside. MSE \(9350 / t\) 4Q 2025.

Upside for aluminium: The US has been destocking aluminium since tariffs came in, but the Midwest Premium is now high enough to incentivise shipments again, we think. With China's aluminium output peaking, and a large smelter planning to shut, the balance looks tighter, while inventories remain low. MSE \(2700 / t\) 4Q 2025.

And a mixed outlook for zinc: An unseasonal increase in China's zinc output during the softer demand season is driving inventory builds and weighing on zinc sentiment. However, low LME inventories bring risks of an upside squeeze, while zinc's responsiveness to recent China policy headlines also suggests room for positive price action if more come through, making the outlook more mixed. MSE \(2800 / t\) 4Q 2025.
**Exhibit 47:** The weighted YoY growth in China's copper demand indicators shows signs of a slowdown, even from a low base in July 2024.

Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research. Weightings applied to YoY growth in monthly grid spend, property completions, air conditioner and washing machine output, NEVs, power generation equipment and solar cell output. Grid spend not yet released for July so June growth was used.

Morgan Stanley Research does not provide individually tailored investment advice. Morgan Stanley Research has been prepared without regard to the circumstances and objectives of those who receive it. Morgan Stanley recommends that investors independently evaluate particular investments and strategies, and encourages investors to seek the advice of a financial adviser. The appropriateness of an investment or strategy will depend on an investor's circumstances and objectives. The securities, instruments, or strategies discussed in Morgan Stanley Research may not be suitable for all investors, and certain investors may not be eligible to purchase or participate in some or all of them. Morgan Stanley Research is not an offer to buy or sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy or sell any security/instrument or to participate in any particular trading strategy. The value of and income from your investments may vary because of changes in interest rates, foreign exchange rates, default rates, prepayment rates, securities/instruments prices, market indexes, operational or financial conditions of companies or other factors. There may be time limitations on the exercise of options or other rights in securities/instruments transactions. Past performance is not necessarily a guide to future performance. Estimates of future performance are based on assumptions that may not be realized. If provided, and unless otherwise stated, the closing price on the cover page is that of the primary exchange for the subject company's securities/instruments.

The fixed income research analysts, strategists or economists principally responsible for the preparation of Morgan Stanley Research have received compensation based upon various factors, including quality, accuracy and value of research, firm profitability or revenues (which include fixed income trading and capital markets profitability or revenues), client feedback and competitive factors. Fixed Income Research analysts, strategists or economists' compensation is not linked to investment banking or capital markets transactions performed by Morgan Stanley or the profitability or revenues of particular trading desks.

The "Important Regulatory Disclosures on Subject Companies" section in Morgan Stanley Research lists all companies mentioned where Morgan Stanley owns \(1\%\) or more of a class of common equity securities of the companies. For all other companies mentioned in Morgan Stanley Research, Morgan Stanley may have an investment of less than \(1\%\) in securities/instruments or derivatives of securities/instruments of companies and may trade them in ways different from those discussed in Morgan Stanley Research. Employees of Morgan Stanley not involved in the preparation of Morgan Stanley Research may have investments in securities/instruments or derivatives of securities/instruments of companies mentioned and may trade them in ways different from those discussed in Morgan Stanley Research. Derivatives may be issued by Morgan Stanley or associated persons.

With the exception of information regarding Morgan Stanley, Morgan Stanley Research is based on public information. Morgan Stanley makes every effort to use reliable, comprehensive information, but we make no representation that it is accurate or complete. We have no obligation to tell you when opinions or information in Morgan Stanley Research change apart from when we intend to discontinue equity research coverage of a subject company. Facts and views presented in Morgan Stanley Research have not been reviewed by, and may not reflect information known to, professionals in other Morgan Stanley business areas, including investment banking personnel.

Morgan Stanley Research personnel may participate in company events such as site visits and are generally prohibited from accepting payment by the company of associated expenses unless pre- approved by authorized members of Research management.
Morgan Stanley may make investment decisions that are inconsistent with the recommendations or views in this report.

Such information is for your reference only. The reader should independently evaluate the investment risks and is solely responsible for their investment decisions. Morgan Stanley Research may not be distributed to the public media or quoted or used by the public media without the express written consent of Morgan Stanley. Any non- customer reader within the scope of Article 7- 1 of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Recommendation Regulations accessing and/or receiving Morgan Stanley Research is not permitted to provide Morgan Stanley Research to any third party (including but not limited to related parties, affiliated companies and any other third parties) or engage in any activities regarding Morgan Stanley Research which may create or give the appearance of creating a conflict of interest. MSTL may not execute transactions for clients in these securities/instruments.
